titleInfo.title: Effects of a Social Robot's Self-Explanations on How Humans Understand and Evaluate Its Behavior

name.namePart: 2020 ACM/IEEE International Conference on Human-Robot Interaction (HRI '20)

mods.abstract: Social robots interacting with users in real-life environments will often show surprising or even undesirable behavior. In this paper we investigate whether a robot's ability to self-explain its behavior affects the users' perception and assessment of this behavior. We propose an explanation model based on humans' folk-psychological concepts and test different explanation strategies in specifically designed HRI scenarios with robot behaviors perceived as intentional, but differently surprising or desirable. All types of explanation strategies increased the understandability and desirability of the behaviors. While merely stating an action had similar effects as giving a reason for it (a strategy or need), combining both in a causal explanation helped the robot to better justify its behavior and to increase its understandability and desirability to a larger extent.
